message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a Lateral collateral ligament tear, as there is laxity at the knee to varus stress. The bruising and pain may also suggest a contusion. Depending on the severity of the tear, treatment may involve rest, physical therapy, or surgery. The patient should not return to athletics until cleared by a healthcare provider.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The varus stress test suggests a lateral collateral ligament tear. The symptoms of pain and bruising of the knee also support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely based on the specific exam findings. It is not safe for the patient to return to athletics until the injury has been properly evaluated and treated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The varus stress laxity indicates a lateral collateral ligament tear. The other options would have different physical exam findings, such as anterior or posterior drawer tests for ACL or PCL tears, and valgus stress for MCL tear. The bruising and pain suggest a possible contusion or hematoma as well. The patient should be advised to avoid athletics until the injury has healed and he can bear weight on the knee without pain. Depending on the severity of the tear, conservative management such as RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation) and physical therapy may be recommended, or surgical repair may be necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The varus stress test suggests damage to the lateral collateral ligament. The patient's symptoms and lack of response to NSAIDs and ice suggest a tear rather than a sprain. The other options would likely result in more severe symptoms and a longer recovery time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Laxity at the knee to varus stress suggests a lateral collateral ligament tear, which is consistent with the patient’s history of being tackled during a rugby game. The other options would have different physical exam findings, such as a positive Lachman test for an anterior cruciate ligament tear. Return to athletics will depend on the severity of the injury and the healing process, which may require imaging studies and consultation with a specialist.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The laxity at the knee to varus stress indicates a tear in the lateral collateral ligament. The other options would present with different physical exam findings. The patient should be advised to avoid athletics until the injury is fully healed and rehabilitation is complete.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presenting with a heavily bruised knee, pain when bearing weight, and laxity with varus stress suggests a tear in the lateral collateral ligament. The other options would present with different physical exam findings such as pain with rotational movements for ACL or PCL tears, or with valgus stress for MCL tears. Treatment and return to athletics will depend on the severity of the tear and may require physical therapy or even surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical exam suggest a lateral collateral ligament tear, which is often caused by direct trauma to the medial side of the knee. The varus stress test confirms this diagnosis. Return to athletics will depend on the severity of the tear and patient’s recovery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The laxity at the knee to varus stress suggests a lateral collateral ligament tear. The other options are less likely to present with laxity to varus stress.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bruising, pain with weight-bearing and varus stress suggests a lateral collateral ligament tear. All other options have different symptoms and physical exam findings. It is important for the patient to follow up with a sports medicine specialist and get appropriate imaging before returning to athletics.
